Theorem 1.  Let D be a bounded domain in E^ vi^hose boundary is of class C^,  Then the Dirichlet problem for the minimal surface equation in D is well posed for C^ boundary data if and only if the mean curvature of Г is everywhere non - negative. 
When the dimension n is greater than two,  the condition of non - negative mean curvature can be satisfied not only by non - convex domains,  but even by domains which are multiply connected.  For example,  the torus generated by revolving the disk { x — a ) ^ - \ - y^ z=b'^ about the у axis has non - negative mean curvature whenever a ^ 26.  It is,  in fact,  only in the case of two dimensions that the condition of non - negative mean curvature implies that the domain D is convex. 
When the boundary data is subject to certain restrictions,  the Dirichlet problem may be solvable even with no conditions on the curvature of Г.  In fact,  as long ago as 1832 this journal published a short note by S.  D.  Poisson in which he announced an existence proof for the problem of least area,  provided the spatial curve ( or curves ) bounding the area lie suitably near a fixed plane.  Poisson's formulation of this result was somewhat vague,  and in any case he never published the proof.  In 1909 the problem was taken up again by Korn in a classical paper.  Korn assumed that the boundary curve Г and the boundary data / are of class C^'^.  Then,  supposing that the C^'^ norm of / is sufficiently small,  he demonstrated the solvability of Dirichlet's problem by using the method of successive approximations ( cf.  also G.  Muntz,  J.  reine angew.  Math.  139 ( 1911 ),  and [ 4 ],  pp.  368—369 ). 
The spatial boundary curve in Korn's formulation must lie nearly in some horizontal plane L.  As far as Poisson's problem is concerned this involves no loss of generality,  since the minimal surface equation is invariant under rotations of the ambient space.  On the other hand,  Korn's result does require that the boundary curve be near L in a particularly strong topology.  Here we shall improve Korn's theorem by hghtening the hypotheses on the boundary and the boundary data,  and by requiring nearness roughly speaking only in the uniform topology ( presumably more in line with Poisson's original intentions ).  The precise result,  which applies equally in any number of dimensions,  is as follows.

The function ^ ( || / ||i,  || / lU?  J^ ) is given explicitly in Section 3.  In terms of the mean curvature of Г it tends to zero as the minimum mean curvature tends to minus infinity,  increases to infinity as the minimum mean curvature increases to zero,  and,  as noted in the statement of the theorem,  is infinite when the mean curvature is everywhere non - negative.  Thus Theorem 2 extends the vahdity of Theorem 1 by making exphcit the relationship between the mean curvature of the boundary of D and the solvability of Dirichlet's problem. 
While we are unable to establish the strict necessity of a condition of the form ( 2 ) in order to solve the Dirichlet problem,  we are nevertheless able to obtain a closely related conclusion.
